Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Near-Field Observations of Preseismic, Coseismic, and Postseismic Slip on the Northern Costa Rica Megathrust
Award.AbstractNarration:
The plate boundary at convergent margins produces most of the world?s largest earthquakes, threatening local inhabitants and global populations through destructive shaking and tsunami generation. An Mw 7.6 earthquake occurred on 5 September 2012 in Nicoya Peninsula, northern Costa Rica directly beneath a network of seismic and continuous GPS stations. It provides a unique opportunity to study the cycle of a megathrust earthquake in unprecedented detail. This project seeks to better understand the preparation process of megathrust earthquakes by identifying slow preslip and/or patterns in foreshock activity, and evolutions of aftershocks and afterslip induced by the mainshock. Our project has important implications for predictability of large earthquakes, the potential size of the megathrust earthquake, the strong ground motions and associated damage, and tectonic strain accumulation and release during an earthquake cycle.

Major research questions to be addressed include whether there is discernible preparation activity before the mainshock, if distinct regions of the plate boundary host coseismic versus slow and after slip, if slip in the mainshock occurs in regions accumulating strain during the interseismic period, whether aftershocks are driven by afterslip or other processes, and what effect mainshock rupture has on seismic velocities and properties of the plate interface. Because we have been measuring surface deformation and seismicity directly above the megathrust for over a decade preceding the 2012 Nicoya earthquake, we can compare the distribution of coseismic slip with the interseismic strain accumulation pattern, slow slip behavior, and precursory seismicity and address all of these questions in a single location. To ascertain whether any accelerating foreshock activity and aftershock expansion/migration occurs, a complete catalog of seismic activity before and after the mainshock is required. We will use all earthquakes in our existing catalog as templates and scan through continuous records to identify additional events easily missed by automated detection algorithms and visual inspection. Event pairs with the highest correlation coefficients will be grouped into repeating earthquake clusters and used to infer slow-slip and afterslip, and track temporal changes of subduction zone interface properties. We will also detect tectonic tremor long before and after the mainshock and use it as a proxy for slow slip and investigate whether tremor/slow slip events occur before major earthquakes. Finally, we will compare high-resolution co-seismic slip with aseismic slip during postseismic and interseismic period as well as microseismicity to understand different frictional properties of the plate interface. Because of the high-quality data collected over the past decade, and the close proximity to the megathrust, our project could lead to significant advances on how subduction zone properties evolve immediate before and after a major megathrust event.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The plate boundary at convergent margins or subduction zones, produces most of the world’s largest earthquakes, threatening populations through destructive shaking and tsunami generation. Because of the significant societal impacts, it is important to understand the mechanisms controlling faulting behavior in this environment. However, the shallow earthquake-generating portion of subduction zones, called the megathrust, is difficult to characterize because it is relatively inaccessible tens of kilometers below the ocean in most locations and large earthquakes occur here with typical recurrence intervals of more than 50 years. We focus on the Nicoya Peninsula in northern Costa Rica because it has a three-decade history of seismic and geodetic measurements on land directly above the megathrust and it experienced a large earthquake (Mw 7.6) in September 2012 providing data to analyze the fault behavior before, during and after a large earthquake. Our results show that the region of the plate interface we determined to be locked prior to the earthquake from GPS data became the loci of maximum coseismic slip. This strongly coupled patch was surrounded both up and down-dip by slow earthquakes indicating a separation in the mechanical properties of the seismogenic zone into strong patches that accumulate strain before and slip during large earthquakes and weaker regions that exhibit slow slip. This underscores the importance of geodetic monitoring of megathrusts during the interseismic stage to identify regions most likely to slip in large future earthquakes.

Early foreshocks (within 35 minutes of the mainshock) and tremor (within days of the mainshock) cluster near the mainshock position suggesting that precursory slow slip occurred and likely triggered the 2012 Nicoya mainshock. Most of the aftershocks identified as occurring on the plate interface concentrate in and around the updip part of the coseismic rupture zone, at the boundary between seismic and aseismic (slow slip and tremor) behavior. The aftershock pattern correlates well with the postseismic afterslip suggesting that the postseismic slip does drive the aftershock pattern.  The lack of deeper aftershocks is consistent with the Nicoya mainshock being a complete stress drop event, releasing all of the accumulated strain in the deeper part of the plate interface, leaving no stress to generate aftershocks. 

A seismic wave velocity reduction occurred after the 2012 Nicoya mainshock in two depth ranges. The shallow (1-2 km) reduction is likely due to co-seismic damage in the near surface layers, while a larger velocity reduction is geographically restricted to the southern part of the Nicoya Peninsula at greater depth of 5-15 km. The deeper velocity reduction is related to weakening of the fluid filled forearc rocks from fracture after the mainshock. The project involved the career development of several graduate and undergraduate students and strengthened international collaboration between the US and Costa Rica.
